29// Assemble the specified IEEE-754 components into the target type and apply
30// appropriate rounding.
31// sign: 0 = positive, 1 = negative
32// exponent: Unbiased IEEE-754 exponent.
33// mantissa: The mantissa of the input. The top bit (which is not encoded for
34// normal IEEE-754 values) must not be omitted. This bit has the
35// value 'pow(2, exponent)'.
36//
37// The input value is assumed to be a normalized value. That is, the input may
38// not be infinity or NaN. If the source value is subnormal, it must be
39// normalized before calling this function such that the highest set bit in the
40// mantissa has the value 'pow(2, exponent)'.
41//
42// Callers should use FPRoundToFloat or FPRoundToDouble directly, rather than
43// calling a templated FPRound.
44template <class T, int ebits, int mbits>
45T FPRound(int64_t sign, int64_t exponent, uint64_t mantissa,
46 FPRounding round_mode) {
47 static_assert((sizeof(T) * 8) >= (1 + ebits + mbits),
48 "destination type T not large enough");
49 static_assert(sizeof(T) <= sizeof(uint64_t),
50 "maximum size of destination type T is 64 bits");
51 static_assert(std::is_unsigned<T>::value,
52 "destination type T must be unsigned");
53
54 DCHECK((sign == 0) || (sign == 1));
55
56 // Only FPTieEven and FPRoundOdd rounding modes are implemented.
57 DCHECK((round_mode == FPTieEven) || (round_mode == FPRoundOdd));
58
59 // Rounding can promote subnormals to normals, and normals to infinities. For
60 // example, a double with exponent 127 (FLT_MAX_EXP) would appear to be
61 // encodable as a float, but rounding based on the low-order mantissa bits
62 // could make it overflow. With ties-to-even rounding, this value would become
63 // an infinity.
64
65 // ---- Rounding Method ----
66 //
67 // The exponent is irrelevant in the rounding operation, so we treat the
68 // lowest-order bit that will fit into the result ('onebit') as having
69 // the value '1'. Similarly, the highest-order bit that won't fit into
70 // the result ('halfbit') has the value '0.5'. The 'point' sits between
71 // 'onebit' and 'halfbit':
72 //
73 // These bits fit into the result.
74 // |---------------------|
75 // mantissa = 0bxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
76 // ||
77 // / |
78 // / halfbit
79 // onebit
80 //
81 // For subnormal outputs, the range of representable bits is smaller and
82 // the position of onebit and halfbit depends on the exponent of the
83 // input, but the method is otherwise similar.
84 //
85 // onebit(frac)
86 // |
87 // | halfbit(frac) halfbit(adjusted)
88 // | / /
89 // | | |
90 // 0b00.0 (exact) -> 0b00.0 (exact) -> 0b00
91 // 0b00.0... -> 0b00.0... -> 0b00
92 // 0b00.1 (exact) -> 0b00.0111..111 -> 0b00
93 // 0b00.1... -> 0b00.1... -> 0b01
94 // 0b01.0 (exact) -> 0b01.0 (exact) -> 0b01
95 // 0b01.0... -> 0b01.0... -> 0b01
96 // 0b01.1 (exact) -> 0b01.1 (exact) -> 0b10
97 // 0b01.1... -> 0b01.1... -> 0b10
98 // 0b10.0 (exact) -> 0b10.0 (exact) -> 0b10
99 // 0b10.0... -> 0b10.0... -> 0b10
100 // 0b10.1 (exact) -> 0b10.0111..111 -> 0b10
101 // 0b10.1... -> 0b10.1... -> 0b11
102 // 0b11.0 (exact) -> 0b11.0 (exact) -> 0b11
103 // ... / | / |
104 // / | / |
105 // / |
106 // adjusted = frac - (halfbit(mantissa) & ~onebit(frac)); / |
107 //
108 // mantissa = (mantissa >> shift) + halfbit(adjusted);
109
110 const int mantissa_offset = 0;
111 const int exponent_offset = mantissa_offset + mbits;
112 const int sign_offset = exponent_offset + ebits;
113 DCHECK_EQ(sign_offset, static_cast<int>(sizeof(T) * 8 - 1));
114
115 // Bail out early for zero inputs.
116 if (mantissa == 0) {
117 return static_cast<T>(sign << sign_offset);
118 }
119
120 // If all bits in the exponent are set, the value is infinite or NaN.
121 // This is true for all binary IEEE-754 formats.
122 const int infinite_exponent = (1 << ebits) - 1;
123 const int max_normal_exponent = infinite_exponent - 1;
124
125 // Apply the exponent bias to encode it for the result. Doing this early makes
126 // it easy to detect values that will be infinite or subnormal.
127 exponent += max_normal_exponent >> 1;
128
129 if (exponent > max_normal_exponent) {
130 // Overflow: the input is too large for the result type to represent.
131 if (round_mode == FPTieEven) {
132 // FPTieEven rounding mode handles overflows using infinities.
133 exponent = infinite_exponent;
134 mantissa = 0;
135 } else {
136 DCHECK_EQ(round_mode, FPRoundOdd);
137 // FPRoundOdd rounding mode handles overflows using the largest magnitude
138 // normal number.
139 exponent = max_normal_exponent;
140 mantissa = (UINT64_C(1) << exponent_offset) - 1;
141 }
142 return static_cast<T>((sign << sign_offset) |
143 (exponent << exponent_offset) |
144 (mantissa << mantissa_offset));
145 }
146
147 // Calculate the shift required to move the top mantissa bit to the proper
148 // place in the destination type.
149 const int highest_significant_bit = 63 - CountLeadingZeros(mantissa, 64);
150 int shift = highest_significant_bit - mbits;
151
152 if (exponent <= 0) {
153 // The output will be subnormal (before rounding).
154 // For subnormal outputs, the shift must be adjusted by the exponent. The +1
155 // is necessary because the exponent of a subnormal value (encoded as 0) is
156 // the same as the exponent of the smallest normal value (encoded as 1).
157 shift += -exponent + 1;
158
159 // Handle inputs that would produce a zero output.
160 //
161 // Shifts higher than highest_significant_bit+1 will always produce a zero
162 // result. A shift of exactly highest_significant_bit+1 might produce a
163 // non-zero result after rounding.
164 if (shift > (highest_significant_bit + 1)) {
165 if (round_mode == FPTieEven) {
166 // The result will always be +/-0.0.
167 return static_cast<T>(sign << sign_offset);
168 } else {
169 DCHECK_EQ(round_mode, FPRoundOdd);
170 DCHECK_NE(mantissa, 0U);
171 // For FPRoundOdd, if the mantissa is too small to represent and
172 // non-zero return the next "odd" value.
173 return static_cast<T>((sign << sign_offset) | 1);
174 }
175 }
176
177 // Properly encode the exponent for a subnormal output.
178 exponent = 0;
179 } else {
180 // Clear the topmost mantissa bit, since this is not encoded in IEEE-754
181 // normal values.
182 mantissa &= ~(UINT64_C(1) << highest_significant_bit);
183 }
184
185 if (shift > 0) {
186 if (round_mode == FPTieEven) {
187 // We have to shift the mantissa to the right. Some precision is lost, so
188 // we need to apply rounding.
189 uint64_t onebit_mantissa = (mantissa >> (shift)) & 1;
190 uint64_t halfbit_mantissa = (mantissa >> (shift - 1)) & 1;
191 uint64_t adjustment = (halfbit_mantissa & ~onebit_mantissa);
192 uint64_t adjusted = mantissa - adjustment;
193 T halfbit_adjusted = (adjusted >> (shift - 1)) & 1;
194
195 T result =
196 static_cast<T>((sign << sign_offset) | (exponent << exponent_offset) |
197 ((mantissa >> shift) << mantissa_offset));
198
199 // A very large mantissa can overflow during rounding. If this happens,
200 // the exponent should be incremented and the mantissa set to 1.0
201 // (encoded as 0). Applying halfbit_adjusted after assembling the float
202 // has the nice side-effect that this case is handled for free.
203 //
204 // This also handles cases where a very large finite value overflows to
205 // infinity, or where a very large subnormal value overflows to become
206 // normal.
207 return result + halfbit_adjusted;
208 } else {
209 DCHECK_EQ(round_mode, FPRoundOdd);
210 // If any bits at position halfbit or below are set, onebit (ie. the
211 // bottom bit of the resulting mantissa) must be set.
212 uint64_t fractional_bits = mantissa & ((UINT64_C(1) << shift) - 1);
213 if (fractional_bits != 0) {
214 mantissa |= UINT64_C(1) << shift;
215 }
216
217 return static_cast<T>((sign << sign_offset) |
218 (exponent << exponent_offset) |
219 ((mantissa >> shift) << mantissa_offset));
220 }
221 } else {
222 // We have to shift the mantissa to the left (or not at all). The input
223 // mantissa is exactly representable in the output mantissa, so apply no
224 // rounding correction.
225 return static_cast<T>((sign << sign_offset) |
226 (exponent << exponent_offset) |
227 ((mantissa << -shift) << mantissa_offset));
228 }
229}

231class CachePage {
232 // TODO(all): Simulate instruction cache.
233};
234
235// Representation of memory, with typed getters and setters for access.
236class SimMemory {
237 public:
238 template <typename T>
239 static T AddressUntag(T address) {
240 // Cast the address using a C-style cast. A reinterpret_cast would be
241 // appropriate, but it can't cast one integral type to another.
242 uint64_t bits = (uint64_t)address;
243 return (T)(bits & ~kAddressTagMask);
244 }
245
246 template <typename T, typename A>
247 static T Read(A address) {
248 T value;
249 address = AddressUntag(address);
250 DCHECK((sizeof(value) == 1) || (sizeof(value) == 2) ||
251 (sizeof(value) == 4) || (sizeof(value) == 8) ||
252 (sizeof(value) == 16));
253 memcpy(&value, reinterpret_cast<const char*>(address), sizeof(value));
254 return value;
255 }
256
257 template <typename T, typename A>
258 static void Write(A address, T value) {
259 address = AddressUntag(address);
260 DCHECK((sizeof(value) == 1) || (sizeof(value) == 2) ||
261 (sizeof(value) == 4) || (sizeof(value) == 8) ||
262 (sizeof(value) == 16));
263 memcpy(reinterpret_cast<char*>(address), &value, sizeof(value));
264 }
265};
266
267// The proper way to initialize a simulated system register (such as NZCV) is as
268// follows:
269// SimSystemRegister nzcv = SimSystemRegister::DefaultValueFor(NZCV);
270class SimSystemRegister {
271 public:
272 // The default constructor represents a register which has no writable bits.
273 // It is not possible to set its value to anything other than 0.
274 SimSystemRegister() : value_(0), write_ignore_mask_(0xffffffff) {}
275
276 uint32_t RawValue() const { return value_; }
277
278 void SetRawValue(uint32_t new_value) {
279 value_ = (value_ & write_ignore_mask_) | (new_value & ~write_ignore_mask_);
280 }
281
282 uint32_t Bits(int msb, int lsb) const {
283 return unsigned_bitextract_32(msb, lsb, value_);
284 }
285
286 int32_t SignedBits(int msb, int lsb) const {
287 return signed_bitextract_32(msb, lsb, value_);
288 }
289
290 void SetBits(int msb, int lsb, uint32_t bits);
291
292 // Default system register values.
293 static SimSystemRegister DefaultValueFor(SystemRegister id);
294
295#define DEFINE_GETTER(Name, HighBit, LowBit, Func, Type) \
296 Type Name() const { return static_cast<Type>(Func(HighBit, LowBit)); } \
297 void Set##Name(Type bits) { \
298 SetBits(HighBit, LowBit, static_cast<Type>(bits)); \
299 }
300#define DEFINE_WRITE_IGNORE_MASK(Name, Mask) \
301 static const uint32_t Name##WriteIgnoreMask = ~static_cast<uint32_t>(Mask);
302 SYSTEM_REGISTER_FIELDS_LIST(DEFINE_GETTER, DEFINE_WRITE_IGNORE_MASK)
303#undef DEFINE_ZERO_BITS
304#undef DEFINE_GETTER
305
306 protected:
307 // Most system registers only implement a few of the bits in the word. Other
308 // bits are "read-as-zero, write-ignored". The write_ignore_mask argument
309 // describes the bits which are not modifiable.
310 SimSystemRegister(uint32_t value, uint32_t write_ignore_mask)
311 : value_(value), write_ignore_mask_(write_ignore_mask) {}
312
313 uint32_t value_;
314 uint32_t write_ignore_mask_;
315};
316
317// Represent a register (r0-r31, v0-v31).
318template <int kSizeInBytes>
319class SimRegisterBase {
320 public:
321 template <typename T>
322 void Set(T new_value) {
323 static_assert(sizeof(new_value) <= kSizeInBytes,
324 "Size of new_value must be <= size of template type.");
325 if (sizeof(new_value) < kSizeInBytes) {
326 // All AArch64 registers are zero-extending.
327 memset(value_ + sizeof(new_value), 0, kSizeInBytes - sizeof(new_value));
328 }
329 memcpy(&value_, &new_value, sizeof(T));
330 NotifyRegisterWrite();
331 }
332
333 // Insert a typed value into a register, leaving the rest of the register
334 // unchanged. The lane parameter indicates where in the register the value
335 // should be inserted, in the range [ 0, sizeof(value_) / sizeof(T) ), where
336 // 0 represents the least significant bits.
337 template <typename T>
338 void Insert(int lane, T new_value) {
339 DCHECK_GE(lane, 0);
340 DCHECK_LE(sizeof(new_value) + (lane * sizeof(new_value)),
341 static_cast<unsigned>(kSizeInBytes));
342 memcpy(&value_[lane * sizeof(new_value)], &new_value, sizeof(new_value));
343 NotifyRegisterWrite();
344 }
345
346 template <typename T>
347 T Get(int lane = 0) const {
348 T result;
349 DCHECK_GE(lane, 0);
350 DCHECK_LE(sizeof(result) + (lane * sizeof(result)),
351 static_cast<unsigned>(kSizeInBytes));
352 memcpy(&result, &value_[lane * sizeof(result)], sizeof(result));
353 return result;
354 }
355
356 // TODO(all): Make this return a map of updated bytes, so that we can
357 // highlight updated lanes for load-and-insert. (That never happens for scalar
358 // code, but NEON has some instructions that can update individual lanes.)
359 bool WrittenSinceLastLog() const { return written_since_last_log_; }
360
361 void NotifyRegisterLogged() { written_since_last_log_ = false; }
362
363 protected:
364 uint8_t value_[kSizeInBytes];
365
366 // Helpers to aid with register tracing.
367 bool written_since_last_log_;
368
369 void NotifyRegisterWrite() { written_since_last_log_ = true; }
370};
371
372using SimRegister = SimRegisterBase<kXRegSize>; // r0-r31
373using SimVRegister = SimRegisterBase<kQRegSize>; // v0-v31
374
375using sim_uint128_t = std::pair<uint64_t, uint64_t>;
376
377// Representation of a vector register, with typed getters and setters for lanes
378// and additional information to represent lane state.
379class LogicVRegister {
380 public:
381 inline LogicVRegister(SimVRegister& other) // NOLINT
382 : register_(other) {
383 for (unsigned i = 0; i < arraysize(saturated_); i++) {
384 saturated_[i] = kNotSaturated;
385 }
386 for (unsigned i = 0; i < arraysize(round_); i++) {
387 round_[i] = false;
388 }
389 }
390
391 int64_t Int(VectorFormat vform, int index) const {
392 int64_t element;
393 switch (LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform)) {
394 case 8:
395 element = register_.Get<int8_t>(index);
396 break;
397 case 16:
398 element = register_.Get<int16_t>(index);
399 break;
400 case 32:
401 element = register_.Get<int32_t>(index);
402 break;
403 case 64:
404 element = register_.Get<int64_t>(index);
405 break;
406 default:
407 UNREACHABLE();
408 return 0;
409 }
410 return element;
411 }
412
413 uint64_t Uint(VectorFormat vform, int index) const {
414 uint64_t element;
415 switch (LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform)) {
416 case 8:
417 element = register_.Get<uint8_t>(index);
418 break;
419 case 16:
420 element = register_.Get<uint16_t>(index);
421 break;
422 case 32:
423 element = register_.Get<uint32_t>(index);
424 break;
425 case 64:
426 element = register_.Get<uint64_t>(index);
427 break;
428 default:
429 UNREACHABLE();
430 return 0;
431 }
432 return element;
433 }
434
435 uint64_t UintLeftJustified(VectorFormat vform, int index) const {
436 return Uint(vform, index) << (64 - LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform));
437 }
438
439 int64_t IntLeftJustified(VectorFormat vform, int index) const {
440 uint64_t value = UintLeftJustified(vform, index);
441 int64_t result;
442 memcpy(&result, &value, sizeof(result));
443 return result;
444 }
445
446 void SetInt(VectorFormat vform, int index, int64_t value) const {
447 switch (LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform)) {
448 case 8:
449 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<int8_t>(value));
450 break;
451 case 16:
452 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<int16_t>(value));
453 break;
454 case 32:
455 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<int32_t>(value));
456 break;
457 case 64:
458 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<int64_t>(value));
459 break;
460 default:
461 UNREACHABLE();
462 return;
463 }
464 }
465
466 void SetIntArray(VectorFormat vform, const int64_t* src) const {
467 ClearForWrite(vform);
468 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
469 SetInt(vform, i, src[i]);
470 }
471 }
472
473 void SetUint(VectorFormat vform, int index, uint64_t value) const {
474 switch (LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform)) {
475 case 8:
476 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<uint8_t>(value));
477 break;
478 case 16:
479 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<uint16_t>(value));
480 break;
481 case 32:
482 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<uint32_t>(value));
483 break;
484 case 64:
485 register_.Insert(index, static_cast<uint64_t>(value));
486 break;
487 default:
488 UNREACHABLE();
489 return;
490 }
491 }
492
493 void SetUint(VectorFormat vform, int index, sim_uint128_t value) const {
494 if (LaneSizeInBitsFromFormat(vform) <= 64) {
495 SetUint(vform, index, value.second);
496 return;
497 }
498 DCHECK((vform == kFormat1Q) && (index == 0));
499 SetUint(kFormat2D, 0, value.second);
500 SetUint(kFormat2D, 1, value.first);
501 }
502
503 void SetUintArray(VectorFormat vform, const uint64_t* src) const {
504 ClearForWrite(vform);
505 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
506 SetUint(vform, i, src[i]);
507 }
508 }
509
510 void ReadUintFromMem(VectorFormat vform, int index, uint64_t addr) const;
511
512 void WriteUintToMem(VectorFormat vform, int index, uint64_t addr) const;
513
514 template <typename T>
515 T Float(int index) const {
516 return register_.Get<T>(index);
517 }
518
519 template <typename T>
520 void SetFloat(int index, T value) const {
521 register_.Insert(index, value);
522 }
523
524 // When setting a result in a register of size less than Q, the top bits of
525 // the Q register must be cleared.
526 void ClearForWrite(VectorFormat vform) const {
527 unsigned size = RegisterSizeInBytesFromFormat(vform);
528 for (unsigned i = size; i < kQRegSize; i++) {
529 SetUint(kFormat16B, i, 0);
530 }
531 }
532
533 // Saturation state for each lane of a vector.
534 enum Saturation {
535 kNotSaturated = 0,
536 kSignedSatPositive = 1 << 0,
537 kSignedSatNegative = 1 << 1,
538 kSignedSatMask = kSignedSatPositive | kSignedSatNegative,
539 kSignedSatUndefined = kSignedSatMask,
540 kUnsignedSatPositive = 1 << 2,
541 kUnsignedSatNegative = 1 << 3,
542 kUnsignedSatMask = kUnsignedSatPositive | kUnsignedSatNegative,
543 kUnsignedSatUndefined = kUnsignedSatMask
544 };
545
546 // Getters for saturation state.
547 Saturation GetSignedSaturation(int index) {
548 return static_cast<Saturation>(saturated_[index] & kSignedSatMask);
549 }
550
551 Saturation GetUnsignedSaturation(int index) {
552 return static_cast<Saturation>(saturated_[index] & kUnsignedSatMask);
553 }
554
555 // Setters for saturation state.
556 void ClearSat(int index) { saturated_[index] = kNotSaturated; }
557
558 void SetSignedSat(int index, bool positive) {
559 SetSatFlag(index, positive ? kSignedSatPositive : kSignedSatNegative);
560 }
561
562 void SetUnsignedSat(int index, bool positive) {
563 SetSatFlag(index, positive ? kUnsignedSatPositive : kUnsignedSatNegative);
564 }
565
566 void SetSatFlag(int index, Saturation sat) {
567 saturated_[index] = static_cast<Saturation>(saturated_[index] | sat);
568 DCHECK_NE(sat & kUnsignedSatMask, kUnsignedSatUndefined);
569 DCHECK_NE(sat & kSignedSatMask, kSignedSatUndefined);
570 }
571
572 // Saturate lanes of a vector based on saturation state.
573 LogicVRegister& SignedSaturate(VectorFormat vform) {
574 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
575 Saturation sat = GetSignedSaturation(i);
576 if (sat == kSignedSatPositive) {
577 SetInt(vform, i, MaxIntFromFormat(vform));
578 } else if (sat == kSignedSatNegative) {
579 SetInt(vform, i, MinIntFromFormat(vform));
580 }
581 }
582 return *this;
583 }
584
585 LogicVRegister& UnsignedSaturate(VectorFormat vform) {
586 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
587 Saturation sat = GetUnsignedSaturation(i);
588 if (sat == kUnsignedSatPositive) {
589 SetUint(vform, i, MaxUintFromFormat(vform));
590 } else if (sat == kUnsignedSatNegative) {
591 SetUint(vform, i, 0);
592 }
593 }
594 return *this;
595 }
596
597 // Getter for rounding state.
598 bool GetRounding(int index) { return round_[index]; }
599
600 // Setter for rounding state.
601 void SetRounding(int index, bool round) { round_[index] = round; }
602
603 // Round lanes of a vector based on rounding state.
604 LogicVRegister& Round(VectorFormat vform) {
605 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
606 SetUint(vform, i, Uint(vform, i) + (GetRounding(i) ? 1 : 0));
607 }
608 return *this;
609 }
610
611 // Unsigned halve lanes of a vector, and use the saturation state to set the
612 // top bit.
613 LogicVRegister& Uhalve(VectorFormat vform) {
614 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
615 uint64_t val = Uint(vform, i);
616 SetRounding(i, (val & 1) == 1);
617 val >>= 1;
618 if (GetUnsignedSaturation(i) != kNotSaturated) {
619 // If the operation causes unsigned saturation, the bit shifted into the
620 // most significant bit must be set.
621 val |= (MaxUintFromFormat(vform) >> 1) + 1;
622 }
623 SetInt(vform, i, val);
624 }
625 return *this;
626 }
627
628 // Signed halve lanes of a vector, and use the carry state to set the top bit.
629 LogicVRegister& Halve(VectorFormat vform) {
630 for (int i = 0; i < LaneCountFromFormat(vform); i++) {
631 int64_t val = Int(vform, i);
632 SetRounding(i, (val & 1) == 1);
633 val >>= 1;
634 if (GetSignedSaturation(i) != kNotSaturated) {
635 // If the operation causes signed saturation, the sign bit must be
636 // inverted.
637 val ^= (MaxUintFromFormat(vform) >> 1) + 1;
638 }
639 SetInt(vform, i, val);
640 }
641 return *this;
642 }
643
644 bool Is(const LogicVRegister& r) const { return &register_ == &r.register_; }
645
646 private:
647 SimVRegister& register_;
648
649 // Allocate one saturation state entry per lane; largest register is type Q,
650 // and lanes can be a minimum of one byte wide.
651 Saturation saturated_[kQRegSize];
652
653 // Allocate one rounding state entry per lane.
654 bool round_[kQRegSize];
655};
656
657// Using multiple inheritance here is permitted because {DecoderVisitor} is a
658// pure interface class with only pure virtual methods.
659class Simulator : public DecoderVisitor, public SimulatorBase {
660 public:
661 static void SetRedirectInstruction(Instruction* instruction);
662 static bool ICacheMatch(void* one, void* two) { return false; }
663 static void FlushICache(base::CustomMatcherHashMap* i_cache, void* start,
664 size_t size) {
665 USE(i_cache);
666 USE(start);
667 USE(size);
668 }
669
670 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE explicit Simulator(
671 Decoder<DispatchingDecoderVisitor>* decoder, Isolate* isolate = nullptr,
672 FILE* stream = stderr);
673 Simulator();
674 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE ~Simulator();

676 // System functions.
677
678 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static Simulator* current(v8::internal::Isolate* isolate);
679
680 // A wrapper class that stores an argument for one of the above Call
681 // functions.
682 //
683 // Only arguments up to 64 bits in size are supported.
684 class CallArgument {
685 public:
686 template <typename T>
687 explicit CallArgument(T argument) {
688 bits_ = 0;
689 DCHECK(sizeof(argument) <= sizeof(bits_));
690 memcpy(&bits_, &argument, sizeof(argument));
691 type_ = X_ARG;
692 }
693
694 explicit CallArgument(double argument) {
695 DCHECK(sizeof(argument) == sizeof(bits_));
696 memcpy(&bits_, &argument, sizeof(argument));
697 type_ = D_ARG;
698 }
699
700 explicit CallArgument(float argument) {
701 // TODO(all): CallArgument(float) is untested, remove this check once
702 // tested.
703 UNIMPLEMENTED();
704 // Make the D register a NaN to try to trap errors if the callee expects a
705 // double. If it expects a float, the callee should ignore the top word.
706 DCHECK(sizeof(kFP64SignallingNaN) == sizeof(bits_));
707 memcpy(&bits_, &kFP64SignallingNaN, sizeof(kFP64SignallingNaN));
708 // Write the float payload to the S register.
709 DCHECK(sizeof(argument) <= sizeof(bits_));
710 memcpy(&bits_, &argument, sizeof(argument));
711 type_ = D_ARG;
712 }
713
714 // This indicates the end of the arguments list, so that CallArgument
715 // objects can be passed into varargs functions.
716 static CallArgument End() { return CallArgument(); }
717
718 int64_t bits() const { return bits_; }
719 bool IsEnd() const { return type_ == NO_ARG; }
720 bool IsX() const { return type_ == X_ARG; }
721 bool IsD() const { return type_ == D_ARG; }
722
723 private:
724 enum CallArgumentType { X_ARG, D_ARG, NO_ARG };
725
726 // All arguments are aligned to at least 64 bits and we don't support
727 // passing bigger arguments, so the payload size can be fixed at 64 bits.
728 int64_t bits_;
729 CallArgumentType type_;
730
731 CallArgument() { type_ = NO_ARG; }
732 };
733
734 // Call an arbitrary function taking an arbitrary number of arguments.
735 template <typename Return, typename... Args>
736 Return Call(Address entry, Args... args) {
737 // Convert all arguments to CallArgument.
738 CallArgument call_args[] = {CallArgument(args)..., CallArgument::End()};
739 CallImpl(entry, call_args);
740 return ReadReturn<Return>();
741 }

744 void Debug();

746 // Executes a single debug command. Takes ownership of the command (so that it
747 // can store it for repeat executions), and returns true if the debugger
748 // should resume execution after this command completes.
749 bool ExecDebugCommand(ArrayUniquePtr<char> command);
750
751 bool GetValue(const char* desc, int64_t* value);
752
753 bool PrintValue(const char* desc);

756 uintptr_t PushAddress(uintptr_t address);
757

759 uintptr_t PopAddress();

762 // margin to prevent overflows (kAdditionalStackMargin).
763 uintptr_t StackLimit(uintptr_t c_limit) const;
764 // Return current stack view, without additional safety margins.
765 // Users, for example wasm::StackMemory, can add their own.
766 base::Vector<uint8_t> GetCurrentStackView() const;

778 // Simulation helpers.
779 template <typename T>
780 void set_pc(T new_pc) {
781 static_assert(sizeof(T) == sizeof(pc_));
782 memcpy(&pc_, &new_pc, sizeof(T));
783 pc_modified_ = true;
784 }
785 Instruction* pc() { return pc_; }
786
787 void increment_pc() {
788 if (!pc_modified_) {
789 pc_ = pc_->following();
790 }
791
792 pc_modified_ = false;
793 }
794
795 virtual void Decode(Instruction* instr) { decoder_->Decode(instr); }
796
797 // Branch Target Identification (BTI)
798 //
799 // Executing an instruction updates PSTATE.BTYPE, as described in the table
800 // below. Execution of an instruction on a guarded page is allowed if either:
801 // * PSTATE.BTYPE is 00, or
802 // * it is a BTI or PACI[AB]SP instruction that accepts the current value of
803 // PSTATE.BTYPE (as described in the table below), or
804 // * it is BRK or HLT instruction that causes some higher-priority exception.
805 //
806 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
807 // | Last-executed instruction | Sets | Accepted by |
808 // | | BTYPE to | BTI | BTI j | BTI c | BTI jc |
809 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
810 // | - BR from an unguarded page. | | | | | |
811 // | - BR from guarded page, | | | | | |
812 // | to x16 or x17. | 01 | | X | X | X |
813 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
814 // | BR from guarded page, | | | | | |
815 // | not to x16 or x17. | 11 | | X | | X |
816 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
817 // | BLR | 10 | | | X | X |
818 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
819 // | Any other instruction | | | | | |
820 // |(including RET). | 00 | X | X | X | X |
821 // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
822 //
823 // PACI[AB]SP is treated either like "BTI c" or "BTI jc", according to the
824 // value of SCTLR_EL1.BT0. Details available in ARM DDI 0487E.a, D5-2580.
825
826 enum BType {
827 // Set when executing any instruction, except those cases listed below.
828 DefaultBType = 0,
829
830 // Set when an indirect branch is taken from an unguarded page, or from a
831 // guarded page to ip0 or ip1 (x16 or x17), eg "br ip0".
832 BranchFromUnguardedOrToIP = 1,
833
834 // Set when an indirect branch and link (call) is taken, eg. "blr x0".
835 BranchAndLink = 2,
836
837 // Set when an indirect branch is taken from a guarded page to a register
838 // that is not ip0 or ip1 (x16 or x17), eg, "br x0".
839 BranchFromGuardedNotToIP = 3
840 };
841
842 BType btype() const { return btype_; }
843 void ResetBType() { btype_ = DefaultBType; }
844 void set_btype(BType btype) { btype_ = btype; }
845
846 // Helper function to determine BType for branches.
847 BType GetBTypeFromInstruction(const Instruction* instr) const;
848
849 bool PcIsInGuardedPage() const { return guard_pages_; }
850 void SetGuardedPages(bool guard_pages) { guard_pages_ = guard_pages; }
851
852 void CheckBTypeForPAuth() {
853 DCHECK(pc_->IsPAuth());
854 Instr instr = pc_->Mask(SystemPAuthMask);
855 // Only PACI[AB]SP allowed here, and we only support PACIBSP.
856 CHECK(instr == PACIBSP);
857 // Check BType allows PACI[AB]SP instructions.
858 switch (btype()) {
859 case BranchFromGuardedNotToIP:
860 // This case depends on the value of SCTLR_EL1.BT0, which we assume
861 // here to be set. This makes PACI[AB]SP behave like "BTI c",
862 // disallowing its execution when BTYPE is BranchFromGuardedNotToIP
863 // (0b11).
864 FATAL("Executing PACIBSP with wrong BType.");
865 case BranchFromUnguardedOrToIP:
866 case BranchAndLink:
867 break;
868 case DefaultBType:
869 UNREACHABLE();
870 }
871 }
872
873 void CheckBTypeForBti() {
874 DCHECK(pc_->IsBti());
875 switch (pc_->ImmHint()) {
876 case BTI_jc:
877 break;
878 case BTI: {
879 DCHECK(btype() != DefaultBType);
880 FATAL("Executing BTI with wrong BType (expected 0, got %d).", btype());
881 break;
882 }
883 case BTI_c:
884 if (btype() == BranchFromGuardedNotToIP) {
885 FATAL("Executing BTI c with wrong BType (3).");
886 }
887 break;
888 case BTI_j:
889 if (btype() == BranchAndLink) {
890 FATAL("Executing BTI j with wrong BType (2).");
891 }
892 break;
893 default:
894 UNIMPLEMENTED();
895 }
896 }
897
898 void CheckBType() {
899 // On guarded pages, if BType is not zero, take an exception on any
900 // instruction other than BTI, PACI[AB]SP, HLT or BRK.
901 if (PcIsInGuardedPage() && (btype() != DefaultBType)) {
902 if (pc_->IsPAuth()) {
903 CheckBTypeForPAuth();
904 } else if (pc_->IsBti()) {
905 CheckBTypeForBti();
906 } else if (!pc_->IsException()) {
907 FATAL("Executing non-BTI instruction with wrong BType.");
908 }
909 }
910 }
911
912 void ExecuteInstruction() {
913 DCHECK(IsAligned(reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(pc_), kInstrSize));
914 CheckBType();
915 ResetBType();
916 CheckBreakNext();
917 Decode(pc_);
918 increment_pc();
919 LogAllWrittenRegisters();
920 CheckBreakpoints();
921 }
922
923// Declare all Visitor functions.
924#define DECLARE(A) void Visit##A(Instruction* instr);
925 VISITOR_LIST(DECLARE)
926#undef DECLARE
927 void VisitNEON3SameFP(NEON3SameOp op, VectorFormat vf, SimVRegister& rd,
928 SimVRegister& rn, SimVRegister& rm);
929
930 bool IsZeroRegister(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode) const {
931 return ((code == 31) && (r31mode == Reg31IsZeroRegister));
932 }
933
934 // Register accessors.
935 // Return 'size' bits of the value of an integer register, as the specified
936 // type. The value is zero-extended to fill the result.
937 //
938 template <typename T>
939 T reg(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) const {
940 DCHECK_LT(code, static_cast<unsigned>(kNumberOfRegisters));
941 if (IsZeroRegister(code, r31mode)) {
942 return 0;
943 }
944 return registers_[code].Get<T>();
945 }
946
947 // Common specialized accessors for the reg() template.
948 int32_t wreg(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) const {
949 return reg<int32_t>(code, r31mode);
950 }
951
952 int64_t xreg(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) const {
953 return reg<int64_t>(code, r31mode);
954 }
955
956 enum RegLogMode { LogRegWrites, NoRegLog };
957
958 // Write 'value' into an integer register. The value is zero-extended. This
959 // behaviour matches AArch64 register writes.
960 template <typename T>
961 void set_reg(unsigned code, T value,
962 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
963 set_reg_no_log(code, value, r31mode);
964 LogRegister(code, r31mode);
965 }
966
967 // Common specialized accessors for the set_reg() template.
968 void set_wreg(unsigned code, int32_t value,
969 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
970 set_reg(code, value, r31mode);
971 }
972
973 void set_xreg(unsigned code, int64_t value,
974 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
975 set_reg(code, value, r31mode);
976 }
977
978 // As above, but don't automatically log the register update.
979 template <typename T>
980 void set_reg_no_log(unsigned code, T value,
981 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
982 DCHECK_LT(code, static_cast<unsigned>(kNumberOfRegisters));
983 if (!IsZeroRegister(code, r31mode)) {
984 registers_[code].Set(value);
985 }
986 }
987
988 void set_wreg_no_log(unsigned code, int32_t value,
989 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
990 set_reg_no_log(code, value, r31mode);
991 }
992
993 void set_xreg_no_log(unsigned code, int64_t value,
994 Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsZeroRegister) {
995 set_reg_no_log(code, value, r31mode);
996 }
997
998 // Commonly-used special cases.
999 template <typename T>
1000 void set_lr(T value) {
1001 DCHECK_EQ(sizeof(T), static_cast<unsigned>(kSystemPointerSize));
1002 set_reg(kLinkRegCode, value);
1003 }
1004
1005 template <typename T>
1006 void set_sp(T value) {
1007 DCHECK_EQ(sizeof(T), static_cast<unsigned>(kSystemPointerSize));
1008 set_reg(31, value, Reg31IsStackPointer);
1009 }
1010
1011 // Vector register accessors.
1012 // These are equivalent to the integer register accessors, but for vector
1013 // registers.
1014
1015 // A structure for representing a 128-bit Q register.
1016 struct qreg_t {
1017 uint8_t val[kQRegSize];
1018 };
1019
1020 // Basic accessor: read the register as the specified type.
1021 template <typename T>
1022 T vreg(unsigned code) const {
1023 static_assert((sizeof(T) == kBRegSize) || (sizeof(T) == kHRegSize) ||
1024 (sizeof(T) == kSRegSize) || (sizeof(T) == kDRegSize) ||
1025 (sizeof(T) == kQRegSize),
1026 "Template type must match size of register.");
1027 DCHECK_LT(code, static_cast<unsigned>(kNumberOfVRegisters));
1028
1029 return vregisters_[code].Get<T>();
1030 }
1031
1032 inline SimVRegister& vreg(unsigned code) { return vregisters_[code]; }
1033
1034 int64_t sp() { return xreg(31, Reg31IsStackPointer); }
1035 int64_t fp() { return xreg(kFramePointerRegCode, Reg31IsStackPointer); }
1036 Instruction* lr() { return reg<Instruction*>(kLinkRegCode); }
1037
1038 Address get_sp() const { return reg<Address>(31, Reg31IsStackPointer); }
1039
1040 // Common specialized accessors for the vreg() template.
1041 uint8_t breg(unsigned code) const { return vreg<uint8_t>(code); }
1042
1043 float hreg(unsigned code) const { return vreg<uint16_t>(code); }
1044
1045 float sreg(unsigned code) const { return vreg<float>(code); }
1046
1047 uint32_t sreg_bits(unsigned code) const { return vreg<uint32_t>(code); }
1048
1049 double dreg(unsigned code) const { return vreg<double>(code); }
1050
1051 uint64_t dreg_bits(unsigned code) const { return vreg<uint64_t>(code); }
1052
1053 qreg_t qreg(unsigned code) const { return vreg<qreg_t>(code); }
1054
1055 // As above, with parameterized size and return type. The value is
1056 // either zero-extended or truncated to fit, as required.
1057 template <typename T>
1058 T vreg(unsigned size, unsigned code) const {
1059 uint64_t raw = 0;
1060 T result;
1061
1062 switch (size) {
1063 case kSRegSize:
1064 raw = vreg<uint32_t>(code);
1065 break;
1066 case kDRegSize:
1067 raw = vreg<uint64_t>(code);
1068 break;
1069 default:
1070 UNREACHABLE();
1071 }
1072
1073 static_assert(sizeof(result) <= sizeof(raw),
1074 "Template type must be <= 64 bits.");
1075 // Copy the result and truncate to fit. This assumes a little-endian host.
1076 memcpy(&result, &raw, sizeof(result));
1077 return result;
1078 }
1079
1080 // Write 'value' into a floating-point register. The value is zero-extended.
1081 // This behaviour matches AArch64 register writes.
1082 template <typename T>
1083 void set_vreg(unsigned code, T value, RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1084 static_assert(
1085 (sizeof(value) == kBRegSize) || (sizeof(value) == kHRegSize) ||
1086 (sizeof(value) == kSRegSize) || (sizeof(value) == kDRegSize) ||
1087 (sizeof(value) == kQRegSize),
1088 "Template type must match size of register.");
1089 DCHECK_LT(code, static_cast<unsigned>(kNumberOfVRegisters));
1090 vregisters_[code].Set(value);
1091
1092 if (log_mode == LogRegWrites) {
1093 LogVRegister(code, GetPrintRegisterFormat(value));
1094 }
1095 }
1096
1097 // Common specialized accessors for the set_vreg() template.
1098 void set_breg(unsigned code, int8_t value,
1099 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1100 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1101 }
1102
1103 void set_hreg(unsigned code, int16_t value,
1104 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1105 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1106 }
1107
1108 void set_sreg(unsigned code, float value,
1109 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1110 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1111 }
1112
1113 void set_sreg_bits(unsigned code, uint32_t value,
1114 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1115 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1116 }
1117
1118 void set_dreg(unsigned code, double value,
1119 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1120 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1121 }
1122
1123 void set_dreg_bits(unsigned code, uint64_t value,
1124 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1125 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1126 }
1127
1128 void set_qreg(unsigned code, qreg_t value,
1129 RegLogMode log_mode = LogRegWrites) {
1130 set_vreg(code, value, log_mode);
1131 }
1132
1133 // As above, but don't automatically log the register update.
1134 template <typename T>
1135 void set_vreg_no_log(unsigned code, T value) {
1136 static_assert((sizeof(value) == kBRegSize) ||
1137 (sizeof(value) == kHRegSize) ||
1138 (sizeof(value) == kSRegSize) ||
1139 (sizeof(value) == kDRegSize) || (sizeof(value) == kQRegSize));
1140 DCHECK_LT(code, static_cast<unsigned>(kNumberOfVRegisters));
1141 vregisters_[code].Set(value);
1142 }
1143
1144 void set_breg_no_log(unsigned code, uint8_t value) {
1145 set_vreg_no_log(code, value);
1146 }
1147
1148 void set_hreg_no_log(unsigned code, uint16_t value) {
1149 set_vreg_no_log(code, value);
1150 }
1151
1152 void set_sreg_no_log(unsigned code, float value) {
1153 set_vreg_no_log(code, value);
1154 }
1155
1156 void set_dreg_no_log(unsigned code, double value) {
1157 set_vreg_no_log(code, value);
1158 }
1159
1160 void set_qreg_no_log(unsigned code, qreg_t value) {
1161 set_vreg_no_log(code, value);
1162 }

1193 void PrintRegisters();
1194 void PrintVRegisters();
1195 void PrintSystemRegisters();

1197 // As above, but only print the registers that have been updated.
1198 void PrintWrittenRegisters();
1199 void PrintWrittenVRegisters();
1200
1201 // As above, but respect LOG_REG and LOG_VREG.
1202 void LogWrittenRegisters() {
1203 if (log_parameters() & LOG_REGS) PrintWrittenRegisters();
1204 }
1205 void LogWrittenVRegisters() {
1206 if (log_parameters() & LOG_VREGS) PrintWrittenVRegisters();
1207 }
1208 void LogAllWrittenRegisters() {
1209 LogWrittenRegisters();
1210 LogWrittenVRegisters();
1211 }
1212
1213 // Specify relevant register formats for Print(V)Register and related helpers.
1214 enum PrintRegisterFormat {
1215 // The lane size.
1216 kPrintRegLaneSizeB = 0 << 0,
1217 kPrintRegLaneSizeH = 1 << 0,
1218 kPrintRegLaneSizeS = 2 << 0,
1219 kPrintRegLaneSizeW = kPrintRegLaneSizeS,
1220 kPrintRegLaneSizeD = 3 << 0,
1221 kPrintRegLaneSizeX = kPrintRegLaneSizeD,
1222 kPrintRegLaneSizeQ = 4 << 0,
1223
1224 kPrintRegLaneSizeOffset = 0,
1225 kPrintRegLaneSizeMask = 7 << 0,
1226
1227 // The lane count.
1228 kPrintRegAsScalar = 0,
1229 kPrintRegAsDVector = 1 << 3,
1230 kPrintRegAsQVector = 2 << 3,
1231
1232 kPrintRegAsVectorMask = 3 << 3,
1233
1234 // Indicate floating-point format lanes. (This flag is only supported for S-
1235 // and D-sized lanes.)
1236 kPrintRegAsFP = 1 << 5,
1237
1238 // Supported combinations.
1239
1240 kPrintXReg = kPrintRegLaneSizeX | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1241 kPrintWReg = kPrintRegLaneSizeW | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1242 kPrintSReg = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsScalar | kPrintRegAsFP,
1243 kPrintDReg = kPrintRegLaneSizeD | kPrintRegAsScalar | kPrintRegAsFP,
1244
1245 kPrintReg1B = kPrintRegLaneSizeB | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1246 kPrintReg8B = kPrintRegLaneSizeB | kPrintRegAsDVector,
1247 kPrintReg16B = kPrintRegLaneSizeB | kPrintRegAsQVector,
1248 kPrintReg1H = kPrintRegLaneSizeH | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1249 kPrintReg4H = kPrintRegLaneSizeH | kPrintRegAsDVector,
1250 kPrintReg8H = kPrintRegLaneSizeH | kPrintRegAsQVector,
1251 kPrintReg1S = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1252 kPrintReg2S = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsDVector,
1253 kPrintReg4S = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsQVector,
1254 kPrintReg1SFP = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsScalar | kPrintRegAsFP,
1255 kPrintReg2SFP = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsDVector | kPrintRegAsFP,
1256 kPrintReg4SFP = kPrintRegLaneSizeS | kPrintRegAsQVector | kPrintRegAsFP,
1257 kPrintReg1D = kPrintRegLaneSizeD | kPrintRegAsScalar,
1258 kPrintReg2D = kPrintRegLaneSizeD | kPrintRegAsQVector,
1259 kPrintReg1DFP = kPrintRegLaneSizeD | kPrintRegAsScalar | kPrintRegAsFP,
1260 kPrintReg2DFP = kPrintRegLaneSizeD | kPrintRegAsQVector | kPrintRegAsFP,
1261 kPrintReg1Q = kPrintRegLaneSizeQ | kPrintRegAsScalar
1262 };
1263
1264 unsigned GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytesLog2(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1265 return (format & kPrintRegLaneSizeMask) >> kPrintRegLaneSizeOffset;
1266 }
1267
1268 unsigned GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytes(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1269 return 1 << GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytesLog2(format);
1270 }
1271
1272 unsigned GetPrintRegSizeInBytesLog2(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1273 if (format & kPrintRegAsDVector) return kDRegSizeLog2;
1274 if (format & kPrintRegAsQVector) return kQRegSizeLog2;
1275
1276 // Scalar types.
1277 return GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytesLog2(format);
1278 }
1279
1280 unsigned GetPrintRegSizeInBytes(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1281 return 1 << GetPrintRegSizeInBytesLog2(format);
1282 }
1283
1284 unsigned GetPrintRegLaneCount(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1285 unsigned reg_size_log2 = GetPrintRegSizeInBytesLog2(format);
1286 unsigned lane_size_log2 = GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytesLog2(format);
1287 DCHECK_GE(reg_size_log2, lane_size_log2);
1288 return 1 << (reg_size_log2 - lane_size_log2);
1289 }
1290
1291 template <typename T>
1292 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormat(T value) {
1293 return GetPrintRegisterFormatForSize(sizeof(value));
1294 }
1295
1296 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormat(double value) {
1297 static_assert(sizeof(value) == kDRegSize,
1298 "D register must be size of double.");
1299 return GetPrintRegisterFormatForSizeFP(sizeof(value));
1300 }
1301
1302 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormat(float value) {
1303 static_assert(sizeof(value) == kSRegSize,
1304 "S register must be size of float.");
1305 return GetPrintRegisterFormatForSizeFP(sizeof(value));
1306 }
1307
1308 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormat(VectorFormat vform);
1309 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormatFP(VectorFormat vform);
1310
1311 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormatForSize(size_t reg_size,
1312 size_t lane_size);
1313
1314 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormatForSize(size_t size) {
1315 return GetPrintRegisterFormatForSize(size, size);
1316 }
1317
1318 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormatForSizeFP(size_t size) {
1319 switch (size) {
1320 default:
1321 UNREACHABLE();
1322 case kDRegSize:
1323 return kPrintDReg;
1324 case kSRegSize:
1325 return kPrintSReg;
1326 }
1327 }
1328
1329 PrintRegisterFormat GetPrintRegisterFormatTryFP(PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1330 if ((GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytes(format) == kSRegSize) ||
1331 (GetPrintRegLaneSizeInBytes(format) == kDRegSize)) {
1332 return static_cast<PrintRegisterFormat>(format | kPrintRegAsFP);
1333 }
1334 return format;
1335 }
1336
1337 // Print individual register values (after update).
1338 void PrintRegister(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsStackPointer);
1339 void PrintVRegister(unsigned code, PrintRegisterFormat sizes);
1340 void PrintSystemRegister(SystemRegister id);
1341
1342 // Like Print* (above), but respect log_parameters().
1343 void LogRegister(unsigned code, Reg31Mode r31mode = Reg31IsStackPointer) {
1344 if (log_parameters() & LOG_REGS) PrintRegister(code, r31mode);
1345 }
1346 void LogVRegister(unsigned code, PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1347 if (log_parameters() & LOG_VREGS) PrintVRegister(code, format);
1348 }
1349 void LogSystemRegister(SystemRegister id) {
1350 if (log_parameters() & LOG_SYS_REGS) PrintSystemRegister(id);
1351 }
1352
1353 // Print memory accesses.
1354 void PrintRead(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1355 PrintRegisterFormat format);
1356 void PrintWrite(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1357 PrintRegisterFormat format);
1358 void PrintVRead(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1359 PrintRegisterFormat format, unsigned lane);
1360 void PrintVWrite(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1361 PrintRegisterFormat format, unsigned lane);
1362
1363 // Like Print* (above), but respect log_parameters().
1364 void LogRead(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1365 PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1366 if (log_parameters() & LOG_REGS) PrintRead(address, reg_code, format);
1367 }
1368 void LogWrite(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1369 PrintRegisterFormat format) {
1370 if (log_parameters() & LOG_WRITE) PrintWrite(address, reg_code, format);
1371 }
1372 void LogVRead(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1373 PrintRegisterFormat format, unsigned lane = 0) {
1374 if (log_parameters() & LOG_VREGS) {
1375 PrintVRead(address, reg_code, format, lane);
1376 }
1377 }
1378 void LogVWrite(uintptr_t address, unsigned reg_code,
1379 PrintRegisterFormat format, unsigned lane = 0) {
1380 if (log_parameters() & LOG_WRITE) {
1381 PrintVWrite(address, reg_code, format, lane);
1382 }
1383 }
1384
1385 int log_parameters() { return log_parameters_; }
1386 void set_log_parameters(int new_parameters) {
1387 log_parameters_ = new_parameters;
1388 if (!decoder_) {
1389 if (new_parameters & LOG_DISASM) {
1390 PrintF("Run --debug-sim to dynamically turn on disassembler\n");
1391 }
1392 return;
1393 }
1394 if (new_parameters & LOG_DISASM) {
1395 decoder_->InsertVisitorBefore(print_disasm_, this);
1396 } else {
1397 decoder_->RemoveVisitor(print_disasm_);
1398 }
1399 }

1417
1418 enum PointerType { kDataPointer, kInstructionPointer };
1419
1420 struct PACKey {
1421 uint64_t high;
1422 uint64_t low;
1423 int number;
1424 };
1425
1426 static V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE const PACKey kPACKeyIB;
1427
1428 // Current implementation is that all pointers are tagged.
1429 static bool HasTBI(uint64_t ptr, PointerType type) {
1430 USE(ptr, type);
1431 return true;
1432 }
1433
1434 // Current implementation uses 48-bit virtual addresses.
1435 static int GetBottomPACBit(uint64_t ptr, int ttbr) {
1436 USE(ptr, ttbr);
1437 DCHECK((ttbr == 0) || (ttbr == 1));
1438 return 48;
1439 }
1440
1441 // The top PAC bit is 55 for the purposes of relative bit fields with TBI,
1442 // however bit 55 is the TTBR bit regardless of TBI so isn't part of the PAC
1443 // codes in pointers.
1444 static int GetTopPACBit(uint64_t ptr, PointerType type) {
1445 return HasTBI(ptr, type) ? 55 : 63;
1446 }
1447
1448 // Armv8.3 Pointer authentication helpers.
1449 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static uint64_t CalculatePACMask(uint64_t ptr,
1450 PointerType type,
1451 int ext_bit);
1452 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static uint64_t ComputePAC(uint64_t data, uint64_t context,
1453 PACKey key);
1454 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static uint64_t AuthPAC(uint64_t ptr, uint64_t context,
1455 PACKey key, PointerType type);
1456 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static uint64_t AddPAC(uint64_t ptr, uint64_t context,
1457 PACKey key, PointerType type);
1458 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE static uint64_t StripPAC(uint64_t ptr, PointerType type);
1459
1460 protected:
1461 // Simulation helpers ------------------------------------
1462 bool ConditionPassed(Condition cond) {
1463 SimSystemRegister& flags = nzcv();
1464 switch (cond) {
1465 case eq:
1466 return flags.Z();
1467 case ne:
1468 return !flags.Z();
1469 case hs:
1470 return flags.C();
1471 case lo:
1472 return !flags.C();
1473 case mi:
1474 return flags.N();
1475 case pl:
1476 return !flags.N();
1477 case vs:
1478 return flags.V();
1479 case vc:
1480 return !flags.V();
1481 case hi:
1482 return flags.C() && !flags.Z();
1483 case ls:
1484 return !(flags.C() && !flags.Z());
1485 case ge:
1486 return flags.N() == flags.V();
1487 case lt:
1488 return flags.N() != flags.V();
1489 case gt:
1490 return !flags.Z() && (flags.N() == flags.V());
1491 case le:
1492 return !(!flags.Z() && (flags.N() == flags.V()));
1493 case nv: // Fall through.
1494 case al:
1495 return true;
1496 default:
1497 UNREACHABLE();
1498 }
1499 }
1500
1501 bool ConditionFailed(Condition cond) { return !ConditionPassed(cond); }

1504 void AddSubHelper(Instruction* instr, T op2);
1505 template <typename T>
1506 T AddWithCarry(bool set_flags, T left, T right, int carry_in = 0);

1508 void AddSubWithCarry(Instruction* instr);

1516 void CompareAndSwapHelper(const Instruction* instr);

1518 void CompareAndSwapPairHelper(const Instruction* instr);

1520 void AtomicMemorySimpleHelper(const Instruction* instr);

1522 void AtomicMemorySwapHelper(const Instruction* instr);

1524 AddrMode addrmode);

1529 AddrMode addr_mode);
1530 void CheckMemoryAccess(uintptr_t address, uintptr_t stack);
1531
1532 // "Probe" if an address range can be read. This is currently implemented
1533 // by doing a 1-byte read of the last accessed byte, since the assumption is
1534 // that if the last byte is accessible, also all lower bytes are accessible
1535 // (which holds true for Wasm).
1536 // Returns true if the access was successful, false if the access raised a
1537 // signal which was then handled by the trap handler (also see
1538 // {trap_handler::ProbeMemory}). If the access raises a signal which is not
1539 // handled by the trap handler (e.g. because the current PC is not registered
1540 // as a protected instruction), the signal will propagate and make the process
1541 // crash. If no trap handler is available, this always returns true.
1542 bool ProbeMemory(uintptr_t address, uintptr_t access_size);
1543
1544 // Memory read helpers.
1545 template <typename T, typename A>
1546 T MemoryRead(A address) {
1547 T value;
1548 static_assert((sizeof(value) == 1) || (sizeof(value) == 2) ||
1549 (sizeof(value) == 4) || (sizeof(value) == 8) ||
1550 (sizeof(value) == 16));
1551 memcpy(&value, reinterpret_cast<const void*>(address), sizeof(value));
1552 return value;
1553 }
1554
1555 // Memory write helpers.
1556 template <typename T, typename A>
1557 void MemoryWrite(A address, T value) {
1558 static_assert((sizeof(value) == 1) || (sizeof(value) == 2) ||
1559 (sizeof(value) == 4) || (sizeof(value) == 8) ||
1560 (sizeof(value) == 16));
1561 memcpy(reinterpret_cast<void*>(address), &value, sizeof(value));
1562 }

2288#ifdef DEBUG
2289 // Corruption values should have their least significant byte cleared to
2290 // allow the code of the register being corrupted to be inserted.
2291 static const uint64_t kCallerSavedRegisterCorruptionValue =
2292 0xca11edc0de000000UL;
2293 // This value is a NaN in both 32-bit and 64-bit FP.
2294 static const uint64_t kCallerSavedVRegisterCorruptionValue =
2295 0x7ff000007f801000UL;
2296 // This value is a mix of 32/64-bits NaN and "verbose" immediate.
2297 static const uint64_t kDefaultCPURegisterCorruptionValue =
2298 0x7ffbad007f8bad00UL;
2299
2300 void CorruptRegisters(CPURegList* list,
2301 uint64_t value = kDefaultCPURegisterCorruptionValue);
2302 void CorruptAllCallerSavedCPURegisters();
2303#endif

2318 // General purpose registers. Register 31 is the stack pointer.
2319 SimRegister registers_[kNumberOfRegisters];
2320
2321 // Floating point registers
2322 SimVRegister vregisters_[kNumberOfVRegisters];
2323
2324 // Processor state
2325 // bits[31, 27]: Condition flags N, Z, C, and V.
2326 // (Negative, Zero, Carry, Overflow)
2327 SimSystemRegister nzcv_;
2328
2329 // Floating-Point Control Register
2330 SimSystemRegister fpcr_;
2331
2332 // Only a subset of FPCR features are supported by the simulator. This helper
2333 // checks that the FPCR settings are supported.
2334 //
2335 // This is checked when floating-point instructions are executed, not when
2336 // FPCR is set. This allows generated code to modify FPCR for external
2337 // functions, or to save and restore it when entering and leaving generated
2338 // code.
2339 void AssertSupportedFPCR() {
2340 DCHECK_EQ(fpcr().FZ(), 0); // No flush-to-zero support.
2341 DCHECK(fpcr().RMode() == FPTieEven); // Ties-to-even rounding only.
2342
2343 // The simulator does not support half-precision operations so fpcr().AHP()
2344 // is irrelevant, and is not checked here.
2345 }
2346
2347 template <typename T>
2348 static int CalcNFlag(T result) {
2349 return (result >> (sizeof(T) * 8 - 1)) & 1;
2350 }
2351
2352 static int CalcZFlag(uint64_t result) { return result == 0; }
2353
2354 static const uint32_t kConditionFlagsMask = 0xf0000000;
2355
2356 // Stack
2357 uintptr_t stack_;
2358 static const size_t kStackProtectionSize = KB;
2359 // This includes a protection margin at each end of the stack area.
2360 static size_t AllocatedStackSize() {
2361 return (v8_flags.sim_stack_size * KB) + (2 * kStackProtectionSize);
2362 }
2363 static size_t UsableStackSize() { return v8_flags.sim_stack_size * KB; }
2364 uintptr_t stack_limit_;
2365 // Added in Simulator::StackLimit()
2366 static const int kAdditionalStackMargin = 4 * KB;
2367
2368 Decoder<DispatchingDecoderVisitor>* decoder_;
2369 Decoder<DispatchingDecoderVisitor>* disassembler_decoder_;
2370
2371 // Indicates if the pc has been modified by the instruction and should not be
2372 // automatically incremented.
2373 bool pc_modified_;
2374 Instruction* pc_;
2375
2376 // Branch type register, used for branch target identification.
2377 BType btype_;
2378
2379 // Global flag for enabling guarded pages.
2380 // TODO(arm64): implement guarding at page granularity, rather than globally.
2381 bool guard_pages_;
2382
2383 static const char* xreg_names[];
2384 static const char* wreg_names[];
2385 static const char* sreg_names[];
2386 static const char* dreg_names[];
2387 static const char* vreg_names[];
2388
2389 // Debugger input.
2390 void set_last_debugger_input(ArrayUniquePtr<char> input) {
2391 last_debugger_input_ = std::move(input);
2392 }
2393 const char* last_debugger_input() { return last_debugger_input_.get(); }
2394 ArrayUniquePtr<char> last_debugger_input_;
2395
2396 // Synchronization primitives. See ARM DDI 0487A.a, B2.10. Pair types not
2397 // implemented.
2398 enum class MonitorAccess {
2399 Open,
2400 Exclusive,
2401 };
2402
2403 enum class TransactionSize {
2404 None = 0,
2405 Byte = 1,
2406 HalfWord = 2,
2407 Word = 4,
2408 DoubleWord = 8,
2409 };
2410
2411 TransactionSize get_transaction_size(unsigned size);
2412
2413 // The least-significant bits of the address are ignored. The number of bits
2414 // is implementation-defined, between 3 and 11. See ARM DDI 0487A.a, B2.10.3.
2415 static const uintptr_t kExclusiveTaggedAddrMask = ~((1 << 11) - 1);
2416
2417 class LocalMonitor {
2418 public:
2419 LocalMonitor();
2420
2421 // These functions manage the state machine for the local monitor, but do
2422 // not actually perform loads and stores. NotifyStoreExcl only returns
2423 // true if the exclusive store is allowed; the global monitor will still
2424 // have to be checked to see whether the memory should be updated.
2425 void NotifyLoad();
2426 void NotifyLoadExcl(uintptr_t addr, TransactionSize size);
2427 void NotifyStore();
2428 bool NotifyStoreExcl(uintptr_t addr, TransactionSize size);
2429
2430 private:
2431 void Clear();
2432
2433 MonitorAccess access_state_;
2434 uintptr_t tagged_addr_;
2435 TransactionSize size_;
2436 };
2437
2438 class GlobalMonitor {
2439 public:
2440 class Processor {
2441 public:
2442 Processor();
2443
2444 private:
2445 friend class GlobalMonitor;
2446 // These functions manage the state machine for the global monitor, but do
2447 // not actually perform loads and stores.
2448 void Clear_Locked();
2449 void NotifyLoadExcl_Locked(uintptr_t addr);
2450 void NotifyStore_Locked(bool is_requesting_processor);
2451 bool NotifyStoreExcl_Locked(uintptr_t addr, bool is_requesting_processor);
2452
2453 MonitorAccess access_state_;
2454 uintptr_t tagged_addr_;
2455 Processor* next_;
2456 Processor* prev_;
2457 // A stxr can fail due to background cache evictions. Rather than
2458 // simulating this, we'll just occasionally introduce cases where an
2459 // exclusive store fails. This will happen once after every
2460 // kMaxFailureCounter exclusive stores.
2461 static const int kMaxFailureCounter = 5;
2462 int failure_counter_;
2463 };
2464
2465 // Exposed so it can be accessed by Simulator::{Read,Write}Ex*.
2466 base::Mutex mutex;
2467
2468 void NotifyLoadExcl_Locked(uintptr_t addr, Processor* processor);
2469 void NotifyStore_Locked(Processor* processor);
2470 bool NotifyStoreExcl_Locked(uintptr_t addr, Processor* processor);
2471
2472 // Called when the simulator is destroyed.
2473 void RemoveProcessor(Processor* processor);
2474
2475 static GlobalMonitor* Get();
2476
2477 private:
2478 // Private constructor. Call {GlobalMonitor::Get()} to get the singleton.
2479 GlobalMonitor() = default;
2480 friend class base::LeakyObject<GlobalMonitor>;
2481
2482 bool IsProcessorInLinkedList_Locked(Processor* processor) const;
2483 void PrependProcessor_Locked(Processor* processor);
2484
2485 Processor* head_ = nullptr;
2486 };
2487
2488 LocalMonitor local_monitor_;
2489 GlobalMonitor::Processor global_monitor_processor_;
2490
2491 private:
2492 void Init(FILE* stream);

2494 V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE void CallImpl(Address entry, CallArgument* args);

2496 void CallAnyCTypeFunction(Address target_address,
2497 const EncodedCSignature& signature);

2499 // Read floating point return values.
2500 template <typename T>
2501 typename std::enable_if<std::is_floating_point<T>::value, T>::type
2502 ReadReturn() {
2503 return static_cast<T>(dreg(0));
2504 }
2505 // Read non-float return values.
2506 template <typename T>
2507 typename std::enable_if<!std::is_floating_point<T>::value, T>::type
2508 ReadReturn() {
2509 return ConvertReturn<T>(xreg(0));
2510 }
2511
2512 template <typename T>
2513 static T FPDefaultNaN();
2514
2515 template <typename T>
2516 T FPProcessNaN(T op) {
2517 DCHECK(std::isnan(op));
2518 return fpcr().DN() ? FPDefaultNaN<T>() : ToQuietNaN(op);
2519 }
2520
2521 template <typename T>
2522 T FPProcessNaNs(T op1, T op2) {
2523 if (IsSignallingNaN(op1)) {
2524 return FPProcessNaN(op1);
2525 } else if (IsSignallingNaN(op2)) {
2526 return FPProcessNaN(op2);
2527 } else if (std::isnan(op1)) {
2528 DCHECK(IsQuietNaN(op1));
2529 return FPProcessNaN(op1);
2530 } else if (std::isnan(op2)) {
2531 DCHECK(IsQuietNaN(op2));
2532 return FPProcessNaN(op2);
2533 } else {
2534 return 0.0;
2535 }
2536 }
2537
2538 template <typename T>
2539 T FPProcessNaNs3(T op1, T op2, T op3) {
2540 if (IsSignallingNaN(op1)) {
2541 return FPProcessNaN(op1);
2542 } else if (IsSignallingNaN(op2)) {
2543 return FPProcessNaN(op2);
2544 } else if (IsSignallingNaN(op3)) {
2545 return FPProcessNaN(op3);
2546 } else if (std::isnan(op1)) {
2547 DCHECK(IsQuietNaN(op1));
2548 return FPProcessNaN(op1);
2549 } else if (std::isnan(op2)) {
2550 DCHECK(IsQuietNaN(op2));
2551 return FPProcessNaN(op2);
2552 } else if (std::isnan(op3)) {
2553 DCHECK(IsQuietNaN(op3));
2554 return FPProcessNaN(op3);
2555 } else {
2556 return 0.0;
2557 }
2558 }
2559
2560 int log_parameters_;
2561 // Instruction counter only valid if v8_flags.stop_sim_at isn't 0.
2562 int icount_for_stop_sim_at_;
2563 Isolate* isolate_;
2564};
2565
2566template <>
2567inline double Simulator::FPDefaultNaN<double>() {
2568 return kFP64DefaultNaN;
2569}
2570
2571template <>
2572inline float Simulator::FPDefaultNaN<float>() {
2573 return kFP32DefaultNaN;
2574}
2575
2576template <>
2577inline float16 Simulator::FPDefaultNaN<float16>() {
2578 return kFP16DefaultNaN;
2579}
